DOC.HEAD: Moscow, Prague to Examine Soviet Troop Presence
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union agreed Wednesday to begin reviewing the presence of 80,000 Soviet troops stationed here since the ``Prague Spring'' reforms were crushed in 1968. Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and Premier Marian Calfa told reporters after returning from a one-day visit to Moscow that a joint commission will be set up in the first half of January. The commission, composed of civilian and military experts, also will re-examine the political and historical events that led up to the Soviet invasion and its consequences, Dienstbier said at an airport news conference. Dienstbier, who has said he hopes an agreement can be reached soon on the withdrawal of Soviet troops, told reporters the commission would ``deal with all aspects of the Soviet military presence'' in Czechoslovakia. Calfa was asked if there would soon be a timetable for a pullout of the troops, which have been stationed in Czechoslovakia on a ``temporary'' basis for 21 years. ``I don't know, but I think we will have results in this area that will satisfy the nation,'' Calfa replied without elaboration. In Moscow, the official news agency Tass announced that the Soviet Union had agreed to negotiate its troop presence in Czechoslovakia. Tass said Dienstbier and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, agreed to begin the talks in the first two weeks of next month. The dispatch did not say the Soviet Union would be negotiating withdrawal of its troops, but the Czechoslovak state news agency CTK has said the East bloc country would begin preliminary negotiations for the pullout of Soviet troops. Dienstbier said he met with Shevardnadze for more than an hour Wednesday. Calfa met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. Calfa said he left Moscow with the feeling that there was ``great understanding for this question.'' Alexander Dubcek, who led the Prague Spring movement crushed by the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion in August 1968, signed the initial document allowing the troops' presence after tense negotiations in the Kremlin, where he was flown right after the invasion. Since the ouster of hard-line communist leaders the last month, the new Czechoslovak leadership has said the agreement was invalid because it was signed under duress. On Wednesday, the Communist Party apologized for its hard-line policies of the past and for abusing its opponents after the 1968 crackdown. Earlier this month, the Soviet Union condemned the invasion as a mistake. Under Gorbachev, the Kremlin has vowed not to interfere in the affairs of its Warsaw Pact allies. Poland, East Germany, Hungary and Bulgaria also have apologized for their roles in the invasion. Dienstbier sai before the visit that any troop withdrawals must run parallel with East-West talks on conventional weapons reductions under way in Vienna, where a preliminary accord is expected next year. Faced with a peaceful revolution, Czechoslovakia's hard-line President Gustav Husak resigned Dec. 10 after swearing in the new government dominated by non-communists. Other hard-line leaders associated with the crackdown that followed the invasion have been ousted from power and purged from the party.
